block.p: The Environmental Protection Agency's report on catalytic converters introduces an interesting dilemma: since manufacturers began equipping cars with catalytic converters, the air in cities has become visibly cleaner, but the nitrous oxide emitted from the converters has enhanced the greenhouse effect, which is altering weather patterns and climate worldwide (front page, May 29).

The Environmental Protection Agency's report on catalytic converters introduces an interesting dilemma: since manufacturers began equipping cars with catalytic converters, the air in cities has become visibly cleaner, but the nitrous oxide emitted from the converters has enhanced the greenhouse effect, which is altering weather patterns and climate worldwide (front page, May 29).
The apparent choice is between short-term health and esthetic benefits and significantly increased threats from higher sea levels, more severe storms, droughts and floods.

If these are the only choices, I say get rid of the catalytic converters and bear the costs and inconvenience of smog. Or there is another course: to replace inefficient internal combustion engines with more modern and cleaner means of transportation.
